publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

monogr.title: Egluryn phraethineb. sebh, dosparth ar retoreg, vn oʿr saith gelbhydhyd, yn dysculhuniaith ymadrodh, aʿi pherthynassau
monogr.author: Perry, Henry

lg.l: IF high conceits and sharpe aspiring wit,
May be aduanced by a lowly Muse:
If Pans rude Pipe by Orpheus side may sit,
If Ioues deare Daughter may hir gifts infuse,
Where dulnes doth hir leaden dwelling chuse:
Then Perries golden Rhetoricke may haue place,
By my plaine lines to get deserued grace.
Within the Tempe soyle of whose new spring,
As from the garden of pure spreading wit,
Sweete chaunting birds with sundry laies doo sing,
And yet one tune their melodie doo fit;
As one small seede may millions more beget:
To water whose sweet bloome and fruitfull bowes,
There flowes the spring that bathed Pallas browes.
And learned Perry pierelesse in thy time,
For none but thou the toungs dost beautifie:
Thou shalt not be disgraced by my rime;
But as desert thy praises fructifie,
So shall thy skill my darkenes purifie:
And when sound iudgment views thy sweet discourse,
Let enuy bite hir tongue by thy tongues force.
